M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, “[u]pon a complaint after a divorce, the court may … make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody, and maintenance of the children as changed circumstances warrant.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a court may modify an existing custody order where there has been a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child, and modification is in the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody adjudication and an appellate remand for further findings regarding domestic violence; it does not discuss the legal standard for modifying an existing custody order. Nowhere does the court state that modification requires a material and substantial change of circumstances plus a best‑interests finding, nor does it apply any modification framework. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the proposition about when a court may modify a prior custody order.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a court may modify an existing custody order where there has been a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child, and modification is in the child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general custody-modification case applying a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard. The court discusses ‘best interests of the child’ in the context of deciding whether to permit removal when parents share joint physical custody, but it does not articulate or apply a threshold requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances to modify an existing custody order. Thus it does not support the specific Massachusetts-law proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not…be removed out of this Commonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The guiding standard is the “best interests of the child”—the paramount concern in custody matters.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody determinations the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and general welfare, and cites prior Massachusetts cases describing the children’s welfare as the controlling or sole question. This directly aligns with the proposition that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern in custody matters.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). Heard v. Heard, 323 Mass. 357, 375-377 (1948). Clifford v. Clifford, 354 Mass. 545, 548 (1968) (‘sole question’ is what is best for children’s welfare).”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The guiding standard is the “best interests of the child”—the paramount concern in custody matters.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets the governing removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and repeatedly describes the best interests of the children as the paramount concern. Although the opinion refines that standard through the ‘real advantage’ framework and consideration of the custodial parent’s interests, it does so within and subordinate to the overarching best‑interests standard. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that the best interests of the child is the guiding, paramount standard in custody-related matters.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt:
“The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

“Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The requested modification is designed to promote stability and continuity in Liam’s routines, consistent with Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), which emphasizes continuity and stability as fundamental to a child’s welfare.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses that in custody determinations it is generally in the child’s best interests to preserve an existing satisfactory arrangement and that stability and continuity with a primary caregiver are of “enormous benefit” to a child. The court warns against unnecessary disruption of the status quo and characterizes attempts to rearrange living situations as potentially harmful. That reasoning directly supports using Kali to justify a modification aimed at promoting stability and continuity in a child’s routines.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “These efforts also reflect the view that it is in the ‘best interests of the child’ to preserve the current placement with a parent, if it is a satisfactory one, and that stability and continuity with the child’s primary caregiver is itself an important factor in a child’s successful upbringing. … If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that modification is proper where a child’s age or circumstances change significantly since the prior order.

The court does not articulate any general rule that modification is proper when a child’s age or circumstances change significantly since the prior order; instead, it applies the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ removal standard and discusses financial changes for child support. Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. Where the parent seeking to move has primary physical custody of the children, the standard governing removal of the minor children from the Commonwealth requires a determination whether there is a real advantage to the custodial parent and consideration of the best interests of the children and the interests of both parents.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that modification is proper where a child’s age or circumstances change significantly since the prior order.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses modification standards under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and explains that a judgment may be modified when a "material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred" after the divorce. The court specifically identifies the mother’s remarriage (a change in the children’s family circumstances occurring after the prior judgment) as such a material and substantial change, and holds that the trial judge erred in concluding there were no changed circumstances. While the case is in the removal context, it confirms that post‑judgment changes in a child’s/family’s circumstances can warrant modification.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 ("Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children"). Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification.

App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is about standards for making an initial custody award in a divorce judgment and the need to base that award on the child’s best interests. It does not discuss modification of prior custody or support orders, nor changes in a child’s age or circumstances as a basis for modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition regarding modification based on changed circumstances.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied).… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.raw_text: Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 272 (2009)
Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.proposition: The Court has discretion to fashion a new custody schedule that minimizes parental conflict while serving the child’s developmental needs, per Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 272 (2009) and Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986).
Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The Zita opinion concerns evidentiary limits and judicial notice in a G.L. c. 119, § 24 seventy‑two hour care and protection hearing, and the availability of G.L. c. 211, § 3 review. It does not address the court’s discretion to design or modify a custody or parenting‑time schedule, nor does it discuss minimizing parental conflict or tailoring custody arrangements to a child’s developmental needs. The proposition about fashioning a new custody schedule is therefore not supported by this case, even though the opinion briefly cites Custody of Two Minors for an evidentiary point.
Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: In a care and protection proceeding, evidence is “admissible according to the rules of the common law and the General Laws.” G. L. c. 119, § 21A. See Care & Protection of Sophie, supra at 105-110 (discussing evidentiary rulings in context of temporary custody hearings); Care & Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24, 27 (1988), quoting Custody of Two Minors, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 552, 556-557 (1985). A judge may not rely on facts that are not properly admitted in evidence.

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: The Court has discretion to fashion a new custody schedule that minimizes parental conflict while serving the child’s developmental needs, per Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 272 (2009) and Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986).
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: This opinion is a care-and-protection/parental unfitness case resulting in permanent commitment of the children to the Department of Social Services. It does not discuss judicial discretion to design or modify a custody or parenting-time schedule between two parents, nor does it address minimizing parental conflict or tailoring schedules to children’s developmental needs. Its analysis focuses on unfitness, evidentiary standards, and the drawing of adverse inferences from a failure to testify, so it does not provide authority for the proposition claimed.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Based on these subsidiary findings relating to the best interests of the children and the ability of the parents to care and provide for the children, the judge found that returning the children to their parents would negatively affect the progress the parents had made in their own relationship and that no future time had been established indicating when, if ever, the parents would be able to care for their children. He concluded, therefore, that the parents were currently unfit to care for the children and ordered the children committed to the permanent custody of the department.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Stability of home and school life is an important consideration, but evolving needs and housing suitability can justify modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses stability (school, extended family, and adjustment to a court‑imposed schedule) as factors in both custody modification and removal, but it ultimately rejects using the child’s current, court‑created stability as a basis to change custody. The court emphasizes that there was no material and substantial change justifying modification and that the move to a new home and school in Rhode Island actually improved the mother’s and child’s situation. The holding focuses on improper reliance on temporary stability, not on evolving needs and housing suitability as a justification for modification of custody.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “The probate judge found, ‘[b]ecause Caleb spends the majority of his week in Northboro . . . most of his activities take place there.’ This was a change in Caleb’s living arrangments brought about solely as a consequence of the mother’s compliance with the August 25 order. That order, entered in the absence of any finding of a substantial and material change in circumstances…cannot form the basis upon which a final judgment modifying custody is granted…. There is nothing in the findings or the record…to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances…as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”

Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Given the importance which attaches to “both parents hav[ing] frequent and continuing association with their child,” DiRusso v. App. Ct. 892, 893 (1981), and the broad recognition of the “interests of the non-custodial parent and the child in visiting with each [other],” Kindregan & Inker, Family Law and Practice § 1171 (1990), extensive adjustment of a support order to accommodate extended long-distance visitation is generally warranted and in the child’s best interest.

Pizzino, 67 Mass. App. Ct. at 870.proposition: Here, both parents now agree the present parenting plan is no longer workable; such mutual acknowledgment of changed circumstances further supports granting this Complaint.
Pizzino, 67 Mass. App. Ct. at 870.support_reasoning: The case concerns removal of children from the Commonwealth and modification standards under Yannas and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30. It does not discuss, much less rely on, any mutual parental acknowledgment that an existing parenting plan is unworkable, nor does it indicate that agreement of both parents about changed circumstances supports granting a complaint. The opinion instead focuses on ‘real advantage,’ best interests, and remarriage as a material and substantial change in circumstances.
Pizzino, 67 Mass. App. Ct. at 870.relevant_excerpt: “Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.”
